  • Formulating a linguistically inspired research question (phonology: segments, phonemes, discrete representations, the lexicon, arbitrary rules) that could be answered by a speech corpus (phonetics: durations, spectra, pitches, silences, noises).
  • Designing an experiment on a speech corpus (selection of tokens and speakers, selection of analysis methods).
  • Collecting the data.
  • Techniques for speech analysis and synthesis.
  • Basic statistical techniques for absolute and relative effect sizes (keywords: power, confidence interval).
  • Automating the procedures for data collection and analysis in a Praat script.
course.lecture_material:
• Book: K. Hayward (2000) Experimental Phonetics London: Longman (available from the lecturer during the first lecture).
  • Book: D. Weenink (2012) Speech signal processing with Praat (downloadable from http://www.fon.hum.uva.nl/david/sspbook/sspbook.pdf).
  • Latest version of the Praat program (http://www.praat.org).
course.goals:
• You acquire theoretical skills to turn a linguistic research question (phonology) into the design of an experiment on a corpus of recorded speech (phonetics).
  • You also acquire practical skills to perform such an experiment and report on it in an article.
  • You will become familiar with some of the techniques used in speech signal analysis, synthesis and manipulation.
course.specialities:
A detailed study guide is available at http://www.fon.hum.uva.nl/paul/expphon/.

The assignments are computer-based. Carry your own laptop.

You may choose to write a Poster term paper on the topic of this module (see description of that module).

MA students must attend 80% of the ACLC lectures.
course.examination:
Your grade will be a weighted average of:

  • Some assignments (55%).
  • Several small written examinations (15%).
  • An open-book test in week 8 (30%, duration 2 hours).

Resit:

  • If you attend the course and do your homework you are unlikely to fail the course. But if a re-sit is necessary, it will be in block 3 and will involve doing home assignments and a long written test (3 hours) on every detail of the course.

course.name: Distal and proximal processes in educational research
course.period: Semester 2 block 1, voertaal English ( February 4th - March 29th)
course.institute: Graduate School of Child Development and Education

programme.name: Research Master's in Research Master of Educational Sciences

course.description: Recent developments in theories and models of the influence of institutional and school factors on learning and development (e.g. assessment policies, standardization, accountability systems, school and classroom composition) are discussed.
course.lecture_material: To be determined.
course.goals:
Knowledge and understanding
• Knowledge and understanding of recent developments in theories and models of the influence of institutional and school factors on learning and development (e.g. assessment policies, standardization, accountability systems, school and classroom composition),
Applying knowledge and understanding
• Applying this knowledge and showing problem solving abilities in common interventions at school and local level (e.g. school improvement interventions, class size reduction, introduction of merit pay, professionalization activities)
Making judgments
• Making judgments of pros and cons of certain interventions based on research evidence.
Communication
• Having communication competences to address professional, political and lay audiences about the merits of certain interventions and the research evidence related to that intervention.
Learning skills
• Having the learning skills to improve both one’s own practice and the research community, i.e. being able to design research and develop instruments that can be of use in this domain.
course.specialities: Disciplinary course VIII
course.examination: Individual paper.

course.name: Logic, Language and Computation
course.description: The course consists of a series of guest lectures introducing some of the areas of research that members of the ILLC are involved in. Additionally, as part of this course, each student will have an individual research meeting with a senior member of staff of the ILLC and with a PhD student working at the ILLC.
course.goals: This course is the central obligatory course for the MSc Programme in Logic in the first semester. It is the time and place to meet for all of the logic students. The course provides an overview of the areas of research that the ILLC (Institute for Logic, Language and Computation) is involved in.
course.specialities: http://staff.science.uva.nl/~ulle/teaching/lolaco/2012/
course.examination: Written summaries of guest lectures and research meetings.

course.name: Philosophy and the Invention of the City
course.description:
Aristotle defined the human animal as a zoon politicon: an animal fit for city life. Cities, according to Aristotle, formed the natural habitat of man. It was only by creating cities that man acquired an environment in which he could fully realize his human skills and capacities. Translated into modern jargon Aristoteles can be understood as claiming that cities make men and women smarter, enabling them to live greener, happier, and healthier lives. It was in cities that man first learned the art of government and self-government.

The Greek word for citystate is polis from whence our (western) notions of ‘politics’, ‘police’ and ‘politeness’ derive. When the works of the Greek philosophers were translated into Latin the ‘ polis’ became the ‘ civitas’ from whence our (western) notions of ‘citizenship’, ‘civility’ and ‘civilization’ derive. All these concepts are informed by the idea of the city. During the course we will explore the meanings of these concepts and trace the philosophies, histories, myths and legends they gave rise to. We will do this against the background of concrete empirical studies of the city.

Topics we will discuss:

  • 1. The rise of cities and city states in antiquity. Excursion to Het Amsterdams Historisch Museum
  • 2. Cities, trade and markets. Excursion to the Albert Cuyp market
  • 3. Athens versus Sparta: two models of the city
  • 4. Plato and Aristoteles on the city: city-practices, government and self-government
  • 5. City states, empires, and the rise of the modern state. Excursion to the city hall of Amsterdam
  • 6. Cities and the formation of social classes: rise of the bourgeoisie and the rediscovery of the value of private life
  • 7. Cities, capitalism, the industrial revolution, and ‘modernity’: from metropolis to megapolis.
  • 8. Cities and civilization: natural man and the city: Rousseau versus Hobbes
  • 9. Cities, alienation and decadence: consumerism and artificial needs. Excursion to the Kalverstraat
  • 10. Innovation. Do cities make us smarter? Cities and industrial policy. Excursion to an industry at the forefront of innovation
  • 11. Sustainability. Do cities make us greener? Excursion to the environmental department of the municipality of Amsterdam
  • 12. Prosperity. Do cities makes us happier? Excursion to a relief-centre for dropouts
  • 13. Migration: the push and pull of cities. Rise of the slums. Documentary
  • 14. Suburbia and the splintering of the cities. Excursion to the Bijlmermeer
  • 15. Cities and development: Charter cities: a new way to escape from poverty?
  • 16. Livable cities for the 21st century
course.lecture_material: Students should acquire the reader Philosophy and the City, Sharon M. Meagher, ed., SUNY, 2008. Further literature will be selected during the course
course.goals:
Becoming acquainted with:

  • central philosophical concepts linked to the city;
  • the idea of the city as the natural habitat of man;
  • the idea of the city as a center of decadence and corruption, the unnatural habitat of man;
  • cities as centers of government and self-government;
  • cities as centers of trade, innovation and ideas;
  • the topic of the “livability” of cities;
  • cities as exemplars of what life might be like in the course of the twenty-first century.
course.examination: Midterm- and endpapers on a self-selected topic, excursion-reports and organization of a mini-conference at the end of the course

course.name: Protein Analysis

programme.name: Master's in Chemistry, track Analytical Sciences

course.description: For the most recent contents of this course and other information consult http://www.few.vu.nl/nl/studenten/studiegids/.

course.name: Managing People Strategically

programme.name: Master's in Bedrijfskunde in deeltijd/ Executive programme Management Studies

course.description: There is growing evidence that managing people strategically is crucial to organizational success, and decisions about how to manage people can have profound consequences for a company's competitive position as well as for individual employee well-being. However, as a lever for achieving organizational goals, the strategic management of human resources is both complex and challenging. What does it mean to manage people strategically? What choices does this entail? And who makes these choices? In this course we draw on the most up to date theorising in the field of strategic human resource management to provide answers to these questions. We look at how organizations seek to achieve a competitive advantage through people, and what impact this has, positive and negative, for people. Finally we examine the role of human resource management policy and practice in promoting ethics and CSR (corporate social responsibility).
course.lecture_material: To be announced.
course.goals: The main aim of this course is to ensure that students acquire a thorough knowledge of the theoretical and practical implications of managing people strategically. At the end of the course students will be fluent in the theories that explain why managing people strategically impacts on company performance. Students will be able to discuss evidence that strategic people management choices also impact on individual well-being. The roles of top management, line and project managers, and Human Resource Management professionals in managing people strategically will also be clear to students. Finally students will learn about the role that HRM policies and practices can play in promoting ethics and CSR (Corporate Social Responsibility). This course builds on a basic knowledge and understanding of Human Resource Management.
course.examination: The course will be examined by means of written assignments. The final grade is based on one written group assignment (40%) and one written individual assignment (60%).

course.name: Onderzoeksliteratuur taalbeheersing
course.description: Deze werkgroep is een voorbereiding op de onderzoekswerkgroep. De studenten bereiden zich door middel van een literatuurstudie voor op het onderzoek dat de basis voor hun onderzoeksverslag vormt. De studenten formuleren een voorlopige onderzoeksvraag en zoeken op basis hiervan naar relevante literatuur. Vervolgens wordt een leesverslag gemaakt. Dit overzicht van de literatuur kan dienen als theoretische achtergrond van het onderzoeksverslag uit de onderzoekswerkgroep.
course.lecture_material: Wordt tijdens het eerste college bekend gemaakt.
course.goals: Zoeken naar en verslag doen van onderzoeksliteratuur die relevant is voor een specifieke wetenschappelijke vraagstelling.

course.name: Lineaire algebra KI/INF
course.description:
Lineaire algebra (LA) is de computationele taal van veel ‘technische’ AI en informatica voor real-time autonome systemen. Je kunt er geometrische berekeningen in doen, niet alleen in 3D (voor robotica, computer graphics en computer vision) maar ook in een willekeurig aantal dimensies (zoals voor de dataruimtes in automatisch leren of datacompressie). Er bestaat veel software voor LA, wij zullen Matlab leren gebruiken.

We beginnen met vectoren als de ‘objecten’, en matrices als de ‘operatoren’, maar gaan dan al snel over op ‘deelruimtes’ als de basis-eenheden van LA. We leren technieken om optimaal te rekenen met onzekere data (kleinste kwadraten), en de essentie van operatoren op een coördinaat-onafhankelijke manier te analyseren (SVD).
course.lecture_material: O. Bretscher, Linear Algebra with Applications, 4th edition, 2008
course.goals: Kan werken met vectoren en matrices, zowel op papier als in Matlab. Kent de belangrijkste vormen van transformaties. Kan geometrische objecten in LA vorm representeren. Kent kleinste kwadraten optimalisatie. Kan operatoren analyseren onafhankelijk van basis (eigenanalyse, SVD).
course.examination: Huiswerk, practicum, en twee tentamens, een in het midden en een aan het einde van de cursus.

course.name: Metafysica en Kritiek
course.description:
In een serie korte teksten heeft Walter Benjamin (1992-1940) laten zien dat de mogelijkheid van ‘kritiek’ een vorm van ‘metafysica’ veronderstelt. ‘Metafysica’ houdt in dit verband allereerst in dat je niet met de realiteit samenvalt, - vandaar ook de kritiek. De kritiek betreft de geschiedenis, de kennis en de macht ( die Gewalt).

Voor wie van interpreteren houdt vormen de teksten van Benjamin het paradijs; zijn teksten zijn vrijwel steeds net iets te moeilijk voor de luie lezer. De kwestie is, vervolgens, hoe Benjamins metafysische, soms platoonse, soms quasi-theologische stellingname uitgelegd moet worden. Benjamin lijkt immers zelf nergens in te geloven. Tenslotte is er de vraag hoe de combinatie van ‘revolutie’ en ‘theologie’ die voor Benjamin typerend is geëvalueerd moet worden.

We beginnen met de Thesen über den Begriff der Geschichte (1940), gaan verder met de Erkenntniskritische Vorrede (1925) en eindigen met Zur Kritik der Gewalt (1921). Van al deze teksten bestaan ook vertalingen. Ook de receptie van Benjamin komt uitvoerig aan de orde.
course.lecture_material:
-  Walter Benjamin / Sprache und Geschichte. Philosophische Essays (Reclam / Stuttgart)

-  Walter Benjamin / Maar een storm waait uit het paradijs. Filosofische essays over taal en geschiedenis (SUN / Nijmegen)

-  Uwe Steiner / Walter Benjamin (Metzler / Stuttgart; in het Engels: University of Chicago Press)
course.goals:
(1)  Inzicht in de relatie tussen metafysica en kritiek.

(2)  Inzicht in de relatie tussen geschiedenis-kennis-macht enerzijds en kritiek anderzijds

(3)  Vaardigheid de teksten van Walter Benjamin te interpreteren
course.examination: Twee papers van elk circa 7 bladzijden

course.name: Energie en duurzaamheid practicum
course.institute: College of Science domein Exacte Wetenschappen
course.description:
In dit geïntegreerde practicum dat in het teken staat van Energie en duurzaamheid komen verscheidene onderwerpen aan bod die de theorie van de vakken Organische en anorganische chemie en Natuurkunde in de chemie 2 in de praktijk brengen. Nadruk ligt op de symbiose van deze disciplines in het gebied van de katalyse en duurzame chemie. Experimenten die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld: Recycling of PET-bottles. Regeneration of valuable materials en High temperature chemistry using a microwave oven: synthesis of coloured glass.
Tijdens dit practicum ligt aanvankelijk het accent op het aanleren van een aantal basale identificatietechnieken. Vervolgens worden tijdens een aantal eenstapssyntheses een aantal, isolatie- en zuiveringstechnieken zoals kristalliseren of sublimeren geleerd. De syntheses worden deels op macroschaal (2-10 g) en deels op microschaal (50-100 mg) uitgevoerd. Later worden enkele meerstapssyntheses uitgevoerd, waarbij het van belang is elk tussenproduct goed te zuiveren en te karakteriseren. De meeste experimenten kennen een 'probleem-oplossende' aanpak, waarbij aandacht wordt besteed aan onderzoeksmethodiek.
course.lecture_material:
John W. Lehman, 'Multiscale Operational Organic Chemistry: a problem-solving approach to the laboratory course', 2nd edition, ISBN: 978-0-13-702840-5;
Practicumhandleiding.
course.goals:
• Vaardigheid in de preparatieve organische en anorganische chemie in het kader van energie en duurzaamheid
  • Een beeld krijgen hoe de (an)organisch chemicus zijn experimentele resultaten verkrijgt.
course.examination: Praktische vaardigheden en verslaglegging worden getoetst.

course.name: Canoniseringsprocessen en cultureel erfgoed 1

programme.name: Master Neerlandistiek: Nederlandse taal en cultuur

course.description: In dit vak staan cultureel erfgoed, de literaire traditie en het proces van canonisering van historische literatuur centraal. In het eerste blok verkennen we vanuit een diachrone benadering, aan de hand van canonieke teksten en secundaire literatuur, hoe canonvorming in en na de zeventiende eeuw verliep, met concentratie op de historische periode. We onderzoeken wat canonvorming is, hoe canonieke culturele inzichten cultureel erfgoed zijn geworden, en waarom de canon zich soms handhaaft, dan weer verandert. Daarbij worden ook tekstedities en handboeken uit een latere periode (negentiende en twintigste eeuw) betrokken. Het blok wordt afgesloten met een take-home tentamen waarin je reflecteert op het ontstaan en functioneren van ons cultureel erfgoed en canonisering. Het is mogelijk de cursus na blok 1 af te sluiten.
course.lecture_material: Wordt tijdens het eerste college bekend gemaakt. Een gedeelte van het materiaal komt beschikbaar via Blackboard.
course.goals:
• Je verwerft inzicht in ontwikkelingen en benaderingswijzen van de historische Nederlandse letterkunde in intertekstueel en interdisciplinair verband
  • Je verwerft inzicht in het ontstaan van cultureel erfgoed en van een 'canonieke' cultuur in de zeventiende eeuw, de verspreiding ervan en de reactie erop in latere perioden
  • Je kunt de ontwikkeling van het debat over de canon van Nederlandse literatuur van zeventiende eeuw tot heden begrijpen en analyseren, en de bevindingen mondeling en schriftelijk op academisch niveau presenteren
  • Je kunt het effect van externe factoren op canonieke teksten duiden, tekstinterne factoren aanwijzen die tot canoniciteit kunnen leiden, en de verworven vaardigheden toepassen in een wetenschappelijk, didactisch of cultuurbeleidsmatig discours

course.name: Rekenen/wiskunde
course.description:
Enkele onderwerpen worden centraal behandeld; daarnaast gaan groepjes studenten zich verdiepen in onderwerpen en hierover aan elkaar presenteren. De geselecteerde onderwerpen:

1. Het KNAW-rapport
2. Procedurele vaardigheden en conceptuele kennis en de verwevenheid ervan (Kilpatrick et all)
3. Toetsen: Nationale en internationale rekentoetsen (oa. PPON, TIMSS)
4. Rekenen door Braziliaanse straatkinderen
5. Rekenen door volwassenen, numeracy en situated knowledge
6. Rekenen en dyscalculie
course.lecture_material:
Er zullen teksten beschikbaar gesteld worden uit:
1. Koninklijke Nederlandse Akademie van Wetenschappen (2009). Rekenonderwijs op de basisschool; Analyse en sleutels tot verbetering. Amsterdam: KNAW
2. Kilpatrick, J., Swafford, J. & Findell, B. (2001). Adding It Up: Helping Children Learn Mathematics. Washington, DC: National Academy Press.
3. TIMSS-rapporten, PPON-rapporten
4. Nunes, T., Schliemann, A. D. & Carraher, D. W. (1993). Street mathematics and school mathematics. New York: Cambridge University Press.
5. Lave, J. (1988). Cognition in practice; Mind, mathematics, and culture in everyday life. New York: Cambridge University Press.
6. Millikowski, M. & Braams, T. (2009). Dyscalculie. In M. Taal & P. Snellings (red.), Interventies in het onderwijs: leerproblemen (pp. 60-77). Amsterdam:Boom.
course.goals:
Je heb kennis van en inzicht in:

  • Misconcepties, relevante representaties en instructiestrategieën voor breuken, procenten, verhoudingen en kommagetallen   
  • Maatwerk, dyscalculie en activerende werkvormen  
  • Onderzoeksliteratuur rondom rekenonderzoek (PPON, Timss, KNAW rapport)  
  • Vaktaal betreffende cognitieve processen bij het rekenen

Je kunt:

  • Opgaven classificeren, foutenanalyse maken van het werk van leerlingen en maatwerk bieden 
  • Jezelf toewerken tot het rekenniveau conform de vereisten voor landelijke referentietoets.
course.examination:
Kennistoets over behandelde onderwerpen, incl eigen vaardigheden en didactiek en de landelijke referentiekader toets.  

Presentatie

course.name: Kabbalah
course.description:
In deze keuzemodule lezen we delen Zohar en van het werk van zes beroemde kabbalisten en bespreken we dit werk in relatie tot hun biografie en intellectuele context. De teksten worden in Engelse vertaling aangeleverd, echter de module staat open voor studenten Hebreeuws. Mochten die zich aanmelden dan lezen zij de teksten in het Hebreeuws en zal er meer aandacht besteed worden aan het taalkundig aspect.

De student is in staat een kabbalistische tekst te duiden en de discussies erbinnen te relateren aan andere binnen Kabbalah in ruimere zin en tevens aan de bredere Joodse religieuze traditie.
course.timetable:
4 uur.

Raadpleeg vóór aanvang van de colleges het rooster voor locatie en tijd: https://rooster.uva.nl/.
course.lecture_material:
• J.H. Laenen, Joodse Mystiek: een Inleiding, Kok/Lannoo, 1998 (of later) evt. Engels: J.H. Laenen, Jewish Mysticism: an Introduction, John Knox, 2001 of later);
  • artikelen in kopie/digitaal: zie toelichting blackboard onder cursusmaterialen;
  • primaire teksten: worden iedere week op college uitgedeeld.
course.goals: De student is in staat een kabbalistische tekst te duiden en de discussies erbinnen te relateren aan andere binnen Kabbalah in ruimere zin en tevens aan de bredere Joodse religieuze traditie.
course.examination: Participatie 50%, take-hometentamen 50%.

course.name: Molecular Biology of the Cell
course.period: Semester 1 block 1, voertaal English ( 3 September 2012 – 28 September 2012)
course.institute: Master School of Life and Earth sciences

staff.name: dr. ir. H.A. van den Burg

course.description:
The course provides fundamental knowledge on molecular and cellular biology.The subjects addressed are the following:

  • Basic knowledge of DNA, genomes, genes, gene regulation, transcription, RNA, translation, gene regulation.
  • Up-to-date Molecular techniques such as PCR, High-throughput sequencing, Microarray analysis, Chromatin immunoprecipitation, Bisulfite sequencing, proteomics.  
  • Cell culturing techniques, cell separation and fluorescence microscopy analysis.   
  • Basic Biotechnology: genetically modified organisms, such as bacteria, yeast, plants and animals.  
  • The regulation of gene expression by chromatin structure, DNA methylation and RNA interference.  
  • Basic knowledge of protein synthesis, protein targeting, protein trafficking and cell signalling.
course.timetable: The course schedule can be found at https://datanose.nl/
course.lecture_material:
Molecular Biology of the Cell, Alberts et al., Taylor & Francis Inc (fifth edition).

Hand-outs & papers posted on Blackboard.

Recommended: Epigenetics, Allis D., Cold Spring Harbor Press, 2007.
course.goals: The general aim of this course is to obtain and understand fundamental knowledge of molecular and cellular processes: epigenetics, gene regulation, RNA transcription, protein synthesis, protein targeting and trafficking, and cell signaling. Students participate in a computer tutorial aimed at mastering basic webtools for genome and proteome analysis. The knowledge discussed in the lectures and practiced at the computer tutorial is the basis for an assignment that aims to train students in a critical evaluation of literature. Through presentation of their topic and feedback of lecturers and their peers, students become acquainted with the scientific method.
course.specialities:
It is recommended to perform the background knowledge test available at the blackboard site of  Molecular Biology of the Cell (6 EC) a couple of weeks before the start of the course. If the test indicates a gap in your active knowledge you still have time to refresh your memory.

Location: Universiteit van Amsterdam, Science Park Amsterdam
course.examination:
To pass the course, the marks of the assignment and exam both need to be a 6 at minimum.

  • Computer practical: 10%
  • Assignment: 40% 
  • Test in third week (theory): 10% of Exam mark
  • Exam: 50%

course.name: Master's Thesis Econometrics
course.description:
Starting the thesis
Students can discuss their research idea’s with a member of staff specialised in the relevant area or with the thesis coordinator. When a match between student, supervisor and topic is established, the student will write a research proposal within two weeks using the research proposal form, which is a template that includes the following items:

  1. Research Proposal:
    1. name, Title of Thesis, Specialisation or Free Track; 
    2. introduction: describing the problem, the setting, the current state of knowledge, using relevant literature and introducing the research question; 
    3. research questions: actual question that the research is aiming to answer; 
    4. methodology and techniques: including the type of economic models and econometric techniques that you plan to build on and use; 
    5. data and/or expected results: indicating the type of results you expect or possible outcomes of your research you anticipate and, if you do econometric work, you should indicate which data you expect to have available; 
    6. literature: key references.
  2. Timetable of activities and details of intended supervision meetings; 
  3. Thesis presentation date, the provisional date when the results will be presented to fellow students and staff and anyone else; 
  4. Check that students have registered on Blackboard; 
  5. Signatures of supervisor and thesis coordinator.

Supervision period
A student has a right to supervision for a period of six months after the start of the thesis.

At the end of the process  

  • There is a public presentation of the thesis when it is virtually finished, or in such an advanced state that it is suitable for presentation. This is to be decided by the supervisor. The provisional date of the presentation is indicated on the thesis form and announced on Blackboard, but can be changed;  
  • The supervisor and second reader determine the final grade after the presentation.
    The following elements are considered: statement of the research problem, structure, originality, choice and processing of the literature, choice and processing of the research methods, quality of the analysis, quality of the conclusion, use of language and technical presentation. The attitude of students will be judged on the basis of: independence, pace of work, handling suggestions, contacts with supervisor and possibly other elements to be specified; 
  • The thesis evaluation form must be filled in by the supervisor, and discussed (if required) with the student, and handed to the BES who will register the grade;
  • The FEB uses software to detect plagiarism (Ephorus). The supervisor submits the thesis to Ephorus; 
  • The final version of the thesis will be made available through the university library at http://www.scriptiesonline.uba.uva.nl.
    The supervisor sends the thesis to scriptie-feb@uva.nl; 
  • If the thesis contains confidential material, the student may ask that such publication is delayed for three years (six in exceptional cases), or restricted to a parallel version of the thesis. A motivated request has to be submitted.

Exemptions   
Unlike for other elements of the Master's in Econometrics, exemptions for the thesis are not granted.
course.goals:
A Master's thesis is an academic paper in which a research question is developed and analysed through original empirical and/or theoretical research, appropriately embedded in the current state of knowledge.

A Master's thesis should include the following components:

  1. a research question, with a thorough explanation why this question is of interest;  
  2. a discussion of relevant literature related to the research question; 
  3. an overview of relevant methods in the literature to analyse the research question; 
  4. a detailed description of the methodology used in the thesis; 
  5. a synthesis analysing the research question based on the methods described; 
  6. a section summarising the conclusions of the research.

The Master's thesis must be written about a subject that is closely related to the field of the chosen specialisation. As a guideline, a Master's thesis should contain 25 to 35 pages, excluding tables and appendices. There are hardly any examples with less than 25 and although there are many examples of theses with more than 40 pages, they often include irrelevant material or fail to be sufficiently concise.
course.specialities:
Students need to register on  http://blackboard.ic.uva.nl, where information, dates, etc. and the research proposal form can be found.

Language
The thesis should be written in English. If special circumstances apply, then, on advice of the supervisor, it can be written in Dutch; an English summary is required still.

Specialisation Track
The research in the thesis should be in line with the specialisation track in which the student wants to graduate. In the free track anything in the quantitative economics realm may be investigated.

Internship
The thesis may be combined with an internship. The activities performed during the internship can be used in writing the thesis and often the host institution has some research ideas. Students should ascertain that the research question posed meets the academic standards required for an MSc degree. Approval by a UvA supervisor should be obtained and the research proposal form should be signed before commencement. It regularly turns out that the demands of companies are too practical and do not have the depth and novelty that a Master's thesis at the UvA would require. Sometimes the question posed by the host institution can be adapted in collaboration with the UvA supervisor.
The final grade is determined only on the basis of the academic merit of the thesis only. The activities are not rewarded with EC’s and the performance during the internship will not in any way influence the grade for the thesis.

Double Degree with mathematics  
Students who pursue the double degree Mathematics and Econometrics or Econometrics and Stochastics and Financial Mathematics have to write a single thesis worth 36 credits with one supervisor from the FEB and one supervisor from the FNWI (Faculty of Science) thus making sure that both disciplines are appropriately represented.

course.name: Tutorial Media Studies

programme.name: Research Master's in Media Studies: Research Master

course.description:
A tutorial has a fairly flexible format. It can consist, for instance, of discussions on the basis of a reading list compiled in consultation with the tutor, or of studying archives or other databases. The exact content of a tutorial depends on the student's interests and study plan, as well as the expertise of the tutor. Note that most tutorials will be on offer in one semester per year only, and that members of staff offering tutorials may not be available due to sabbaticals or other obligations. The order in which electives and tutorials are taken by students may vary.

Please note: a tutorial miminally comprises 6 EC (basic level) and maximally 12 EC (advanced level). All staff members offering tutorials offer the 6 EC basic level tutorial. This basic level tutorial takes place in block 2. Most, but not all staff members, offer the opportunity to follow up this basic tutorial with a sequel, for a total of 12 EC; some only offer the basic + advanced levels together. The advanced level is always scheduled in block 3.

Students can only follow the advanced level if they have done the basic level. Students opting to complete only the basic level tutorial (6 C) will have to do a summer or winter school as organized by one of the research schools in block 3 for 6 EC.

List of tutorials on offer in 2012-2013

SEMESTER 1

Practice as Theory in Age of Critical Discourse (Dr. Catherine Lord, C.M.Lord@uva.nl, 6 or 12 EC). Current academic practices have expanded to absorb artistic practices. This means that in the academy, research can now be run through artistic forms. An area of concern such as identity, a paradigm which constantly recurs in cultural and media studies, such as psychoanalysis, can be examined not just through the writing of articles, but through the writing of plays, the making of films, prose fiction and other artistic practices that may be relevant. Practice as Theory examines film makers who run an academic agenda, such as Laura Mulvey and Peter Greenaway and philosophers of the visual who have themselves written fiction or write essays that can be read as aesthetic works, in this regards, the work of John Berger is noteworthy. The work of Godard and Marker offers examples of aesthetic practices which can be read as essays, just as there are essayists who explore their conceptual themes in film work. Practice as Theory encourages students to bring their own examples from a field which is still in its early stages. Readings will be based on student choices.

Film Analysis (Dr. Gerwin van der Pol, G.W.vanderPol@uva.nl, 6 EC or 12 EC). The student analyses and compares the narrative structure and stylistic/aesthetic aspects of a recent narrative film. Using classical texts, students learn to apply existing models for their own analyses. Students learn to understand the difference between interpretation and over-interpretation. At the end of the tutorial, the student should be capable of writing a full-blown film analysis, and demonstrate how this analysis can be deployed in a theoretical argument. The assignments consist of writing a number of short intermediate papers about certain aspects of a film. This concludes block 2 (for 6 ECTS) In block 3 we will work towards a joint project: a full analysis of another film (for another 6 ECTS) In several meetings with the tutor the student is expected to explain and defend the analyses provided in his/her papers.

Methods in Media (Prof. Richard Rogers, R.A.Rogers@uva.nl, for 12 EC only). Digital studies on culture may be distinguished from cultural studies of the digital at least in terms of method. The tutorial takes up the question of the dominant methods associated with particular media, e.g., audience research and diary-writing for television. It subsequently inquires into how methods migrate from one medium to another, and the productivity of such new migratory patterns, e.g., studying the demographics of users of social networking sites. What kinds of findings may be made by digitized methods, such as online surveys? Finally, the tutorial inquires into “methods in digital media,” that is, the methods used by Internet devices and cultures, such as search engines and folksonomy. What kinds of questions may be posed, and findings made?

The Global Circulation of Moving: Approaches and Methods (Dr. Alexandra Schneider, a.schneider@uva.nl, 6 EC). This tutorial looks at current phenomena of global and local circulation of moving images with a focus on film. The aim is to explore different methodologies (distant reading, political economy, ethnography etc.) and theoretical approaches to what is generally known as cultural globalization. Issues at stake include copyright issues and copy-paste practices and encompass legal, political and aesthetic questions. Drawing on recent critical literature we will examine and evaluate scholarly tools that may be useful for the analysis of the global (transnational) circulation of moving images. Readings will be based on student choices.

Media Environments (Dr. Thomas Poell, t.poell@uva.nl, 6 or 12 EC). To understand the political, social, and cultural impact of particular media, it is vital to study how they interact with other media. Newspapers, television talk shows, search engines, blogs, and video sharing websites, do not operate in isolation, but these media are part of integrated media environments. This tutorial examines, on the one hand, the main theoretical approaches to the study of these environments through the work of among others Matthew Fuller, Mizuko Ito, Axel Bruns, Henry Jenkins, Chris Atton, and Richard Grusin. On the other hand, the tutorial investigates how we can use these theoretical perspectives to study actual conflicts, events, or settings in which different media interact with each other.

Social media and the analysis of platforms (Prof. José van Dijck, j.f.t.m.vanDijck@uva.nl, 6 EC or 12 EC). Social media platforms have waxed and waned in the history of the Web 2.0 and are still very much in flux. Major social media platforms are becoming more dominant (Facebook, YouTube), as smaller ones either diminish in size or, constrastingly, suddenly gain influence and users. In this tutorial, we will look at various theoretical strands of research: platform studies, interface analysis and user studies. A few major platforms will be used as examples: Facebook and Twitter. Each participant is asked to choose a particular strand of theory as well as a specific platform for analysis; these choices which will be the focus for a literature review and a paper that will result in a research proposal.

Blogs and the Public Sphere (Dr.ir. Jaap Kamps, kamps@uva.nl 6 EC or 12 EC). The advent of the Web has had a revolutionary impact on how we acquire, share and publish information. In fact, it has a fundamental impact on our daily lives that increasingly take place "on the Web." The "Social" Web has a multitude of personal, subjective content: billions of individuals voice their personal views on virtually any topics in blogs, social networks, and other collaborative sites. This is in sharp contrast with conventional media such as television and newspapers that de-emphasize subjective content in favor of relatively objective reporting. Students will read a selection of literature on the social web and on affective or emotive content in media (from media studies, communication science, psychology, and linguistics). In parallel, they will conduct exploratory experiments using live Web data.

Representation, Testimony and Remembrance: On Media and Genocides (Dr. Marie Lous Aude Baronian, M.A.M.B.LousBaronian@uva.nl, 6 or 12 EC). Concepts of representation, testimony and memory will be the starting points for analysing the role of media (Film, TV, new media, photography, video) in bearing witness to genocides. In this tutorial we will pay special attention to “denied” or “forgotten” genocidal catastrophes such as the Tutsis genocide in Rwanda and the Armenian genocide because of the strong lack of representation and distribution that characterize them. Emphasis could be either on the mnemonic function of visual media or on the difficulty (or impossibility) of representing genocides. Whereas the tutor will provide specific media objects to study, students will be encouraged to look for “new” and most recent media representation dealing with the issue.

Cinematic City (Dr. Floris Paalman, F.J.J.W.Paalman@uva.nl, 6 or 12 EC). Worldwide urbanisation and the proliferation of the moving image are emblematic for modern culture. Various scholars, from different disciplines, assume that these processes are interlinked. Numerous studies have been carried out regarding the metropolis in connection to fiction film and avant-garde experiments (e.g. city-symphonies). Visions upon urban life and culture have been analysed, how filmmakers have informed a.o. writers, artists, architects, and vice versa, and how cinema has provided a mode of perception. More recently, attention is also paid to different urban configurations (e.g. networks of small and medium cities, company towns, tourist destinations) and other media productions (e.g. news programmes, documentaries, industrial and educational films, commercials, television shows). Issues of city branding have been tackled (e.g . city promotion through media, stimulation of media production and creative industries, film festivals, media events etc.), and various other roles that media have played within the city, in different settings and for different groups of people. An important strand within the discourse on cinema and the city is the study of the relationship between on the one hand media and on the other architecture and urban design. It varies from analysis of space in films to the use of media as design tools, from the simulation of urban plans to media displays in public space and smart architecture. Such studies touch upon issues of time and space, image and object, as well as identity and structure.

SEMESTER 2

Cinematic Emotions (Dr. Tarja Laine, T.Laine@uva.nl, 6 EC or 12 EC). It is generally acknowledged that cinematic emotions exhibit a great deal of variety that requires further scrutiny. In this tutorial, we will be searching for a method that takes its distance from the acts of meaning-making based on theories from “outside cinema” in order to endorse a mode of thinking “through” emotions that emerges from a direct engagement with the cinematic. It has often been suggested that cinematic emotions are results of concerns for particular characters that are felt as changes in action readiness. Yet more often than not cinematic emotions are of a different order from those that arise, say, as a result of character alignment or allegiance (Murray Smith). For instance, the transmission of emotion in the cinematic experience can be found in the “emotive focus” within the film itself that the spectator “shares” through a certain transmissive logic. Not only do different films have different emotive focuses, but they also have different means by which to transmit the emotive focus in question to the spectator. As a result, a unified theory that explains all sorts of emotional responses to all sorts of films becomes an impossibility. In this spirit, this tutorial aims to explore and to understand the complex unfolding of emotional processes in the cinematic experience through multiple approaches, such as analytical philosophy, cognitive psychology, narratology, critical theory and phenomenology. Since emotions play a prominent role in the cinematic experience that cannot be pinpointed in any exhaustive manner, the appropriate approach in studying cinematic emotions depends on each scholar’s specific goal.

Archives, memory and heritage (Prof. Theo Thomassen, ( t.h.p.m.thomassen@uva.nl, 6 EC). Memory has never been closer to us, yet never more difficult to understand. Over the last decades, memory has become a growing field of research and particularly mediated memory related to heritage and identity. In: Memory, Histories, Theories, Debates, edited by Susannah Radstone and Bill Schwartz (New York, Fordham University Press, 2010) the work is reconstructed of the great philosophical and literary figures of the past two centuries who recast the concept of memory and brought it to the forefront of the modernist and postmodernist imagination - among them Bergson, Halbwachs, Freud, Proust, Benjamin, Adorno, and Deleuze. This book, which includes more than thirty specially commissioned essays, will be the starting point of this tutorial, which will particularly focus on archives, memory and heritage.

Adventures in Multimodality (Dr. Charles Forceville, c.j.forceville@uva.nl, 6 or 12 EC). Narration, communication, and persuasion increasingly combine language, visuals, sound, music, gesture – and perhaps even the modes of smell, taste, and tactility – to make an optimal impact on an audience’s thoughts and feelings – and possibly on its future actions. But how are multimodal discourses built up to achieve their narrative or rhetorical purposes? In this tutorial we will examine and evaluate scholarly tools that may be useful for the analysis of multimodal discourse. Discourses worth investigating include, but are not restricted to, documentary film, animation, cartoons, comics & graphic novels, websites, and games. Systematic analysis of a corpus of “texts” (in any medium) will be expected in the final essay. For more information about angles and approaches, see the AIM blog at http://muldisc.wordpress.com/

Theorising Medium Specificity (Prof. Richard Rogers, R.A.Rogers@uva.nl, 6 EC). Medium specificity is not only how one sub-divides disciplinary commitments in media studies according to the primary objects of study: film, radio, television, etc. It is also a particular plea to take seriously ontological distinctiveness, though the means by which the ontologies are built differ. To the literary scholar and media theorist, Marshall McLuhan, media are specific in how they engage the senses. To the cultural theorist, Raymond Williams, media are specific in the forms they assume – forms that are shaped by the dominant actors to serve interests. To Katherine Hayles, media have characteristics in their materiality; book specifies, whilst text does not. Her proposal for ‘media-specific analysis’ is a comparative media studies program, which takes instantiated characteristics of media (e.g., hypertext in digital media), and enquires into their (simulated) presence in other media (e.g., print). By engaging with work by Manovich, Fuller, Hayles, Williams, McLuhan and others, the tutorial theorizes medium specificity.

Sound Media and Aesthetics (Dr Carolyn Birdsall, C.J.Birdsall@uva.nl, 6 or 12 EC). In recent decades there has been a growing interest in sound, listening and audio culture within the broader field of media studies. In this tutorial, we will initially examine the significance and emergence of modern sound media (from the gramophone and wireless radio to tape technology and digital sound). After engaging with media historical perspectives, we will discuss the aesthetic dimensions to sound practice, its media-specific forms and modes of listening. The tutorial will introduce key concepts for sound analysis (including voice, noise, music, rhythm, acoustic space) and theoretical texts by McLuhan, Kittler, Chion, Altman, and others. Participants will be invited to discuss these texts in relation to contemporary examples, and to develop their own research interest with a specific object of analysis.

Smart Environments (Dr. Jan Simons, J.A.A.Simons@uva.nl 6 or 12 EC). Together with the computer, the Internet has moved beyond the desktop and has become almost ubiquitous. Wherever they go, users have become nodes in multiple local and global networks such as Local Area Networks (LANs), Wide Area Networks (WANs), Wi-Fi networks, Bluetooth connections, RFID tags, 3G and 4G mobile phone networks, etc. Nowadays human users are no longer the only “nodes” in these networks (if they ever were), but increasingly share this role with so-called “smart objects” and “responsive environments” that are equipped with sensors and actuators that allow them to anticipate and respond to the perceived needs and desires of users of private and public spaces. Today, there are already more objects hooked up to all sorts of networks than human users: the Internet has become an “Internet of Things.” The rise of “the Internet of Things” poses challenges not only to the architects and designers of our everyday environments, but also raises philosophical and ethical issues with regard to the relationship between human, embodied experience and an increasingly technologically mediated and animated environment. This tutorial will explore some of the state-of-the-art projects in urban design and look into the cultural, philosophical, and experiential effects of these developments.

Stardom and celebrity in media culture (Dr. Jaap Kooijman, J.W.Kooijman@uva.nl, 6 or 12 EC).In our contemporary audiovisual media culture, the boundaries between information and entertainment, between politics and spectacle, are constantly challenged. The political realm has become intertwined with popular culture. Politicians function as media personalities; celebrities possess effective voices in the public debate; citizens are reduced to consumers; political issues are addressed on popular forums as television talk shows and music videos. In this tutorial, we read canonical texts used in the study of stardom and celebrity, ranging from Roland Barthes and Jean Baudrillard to Richard Dyer and Christine Geragthy. Moreover, we discuss the ways stars and celebrities can be analyzed as embodiments of larger ideological questions within pop culture and politics.

Software as Object of Cultural Analysis (Dr. Bernhard Rieder, rieder@uva.nl, 6 EC). Software is a puzzling object. Written like text but functioning like a machine it differs from other forms of technology/media by the way it is built, distributed, and used. At the same time, software has become ubiquitous: from enterprise management to online environments, from the most critical to the very banal, computer programs are part of a continuously growing part of everyday practices. But how to study these objects, how to conceive them intellectually? This tutorial aims at having a closer look at the emerging field of “software studies” but will also consider literature concerning adjunct subjects that may prove useful for understanding the phenomenon at hand, such as the history and theory of statistics, accounting, and information processing. Our guiding question will be: how does software introduce specific modes of structuring communication, interaction, and cultural production?

Text and image relations in argumentative discourses (Dr. Assimakis Tseronis, A.Tseronis@uva.nl, 6 or 12 EC). What is the role of images in argumentative discourse? How do text and image interact in discourses that seek to persuade an audience and what are the effects of this synergy? In this tutorial, tools and concepts from discourse analysis and argumentation studies are introduced and the extent to which they can be useful in analyzing and interpreting the use of images in argumentative discourse is discussed. The reading material draws from literature in discourse analysis, argumentation studies and rhetoric, visual communication and multimodal analysis. During the tutorial, students are expected to apply the tools to which they are introduced on their own material, in which static or moving images interact with discourse, upon condition that the discourse under study is analysed from an argumentative perspective. Depending on the students’ interests, the focus of the tutorial may vary from questions in visual rhetoric, to argumentative analysis of multimodal discourse, to theoretical and methodological issues arising from the application of the proposed tools and concepts in multimodal analysis.

Screening Public Culture (Dr. Anne Kutritz, a.m.kustritz@uva.nl, 6 or 12 EC). This tutorial attempts two complementary interpretations of the title: on the one hand, to study how the television "screens" and thus selects for particular interpretations of acceptable or normative public culture, while on the other hand also examining how television "screens out" certain identities and ways of living from the public culture it imagines. In the wake of media convergence some theorists suggest that television no longer maintains its function as the privileged site of cultural and ideological reproduction; thus this tutorial investigates the way that television shares this function with a variety of digital media while at the same time still maintaining its position of influence even as the mass-ness of mass culture changes. Writers of interest include Michael Warner, Lauren Berlant, Judith Halberstam, JK Puar, and Melanie Kohnen.

Worlds at the Edge: Ecocriticism and Media (Dr. Catherine Lord, C.M.Lord@uva.nl, 6 or 12 EC). The architect of the “Gaia Hypothesis,” James Lovelock, has argued compellingly that humans need to wake up to the fact that we are not the centre of the planet. Global ‘heating’will change our lives both physically and culturally. Cinema, television, new media and literature are part of the global, local and cultural landscapes responding to climate change. Richard Kerridge argues that ecocriticism “seeks to evaluate texts and ideas in terms of their coherence and usefulness to environmental crisis” (1998: 5). Despite its literary antecedents, ecocriticism needs to discover the trans-disciplinary arena of film, television and new media, all of which demand both an ecocritical and, an ’eco-creative’ approach. The aim will be to bring these media objects into creative dialogue with ecocritical concepts such as the “environmental imagination” (Buell 2001). Attention will be given to ‘images’ and ‘narratives’ that form an intermedial space between human culture and planetary life. We will read both classical and contemporary texts in the field, analyzing the productive tensions between classic ‘texts’ from ecocriticism (Carson, Leopold) with a range of media case studies, including Avatar (Cameron, 2009), The Day the Earth Stood Still (Derrickson, 2008), The Age of Stupid (Armstrong, 2008) and National Geographic and Discovery Channel websites.

There is one tutorial that is scheduled in both semesters:

please contact Dr. Jaap Kooijman ( J.W.Kooijman@uva.nl),  before 30 August 2012, for details:

Cross-Media Seminar: Cultural Reinvention and Technologies of the Mediated Subject Christoph Lindner et al. 2 x 6 EC or 12 EC). Crossmediated technological developments are transforming theories of subjectivity. Interaction, reception, manipulation – these characterizations of audiences/publics/users will be explored from the vantage point of media studies, the social sciences, and the humanities in general. Further, conceptualizations of cultural objects need revisiting given the transformations across media, as well as the disciplinary approaches to studying them. For example: TV as object/text/ experience; New Media as social media, political tool, surveillance technology; and literature and cinema as ontological objects, sensorial encounters.
Technology, techne, and technique have become central terms across disciplines in exploring the subject/self. Further, transformation has been central to the history of technology, and takes on an even more intense form today. This term “technology” – whose centrality in television studies is also related to the fields of cinema, literature, and philosophy – will be the starting point for an in-depth investigation of a cross-disciplinary and intermedial understanding of the evolving relation between the mediated self and technological transformations. “Cultural Reinvention” captures this evolving dynamic between the mediated subject and transformative media technologies from a crossmedia and interdisciplinary perspective. The seminar is open to all interested staff, PhD candidates, RMA/MA students, and practitioners, including members of NICA (Netherlands Institute for Cultural Analysis) and RMeS (Research School for Media Studies). Research Masters students from the UvA and other Dutch universities can receive tutorial credit for participation in the seminar.
course.timetable: Time slots for tutorials are determined by the tutor, in consultation with the students that have successfully applied for the tutorial.
course.lecture_material: Variable
course.goals:
At the end of the course the student has intensively familiarized him/herself with specialist literature, research methods and current discussions in Media Studies in the field of the tutorial chosen.

Tutorials offer the opportunity to become intimately acquainted with specialist literature, research methods and current discussions in Media Studies. Tutorials may pertain to matters of theory, but may also aim at in-depth knowledge of a specific corpus.
course.specialities:
Tutorials are intensive, intellectually stimulating seminars on topics in which the tutor is an expert. Tutorials are usually initiated by members of staff, but may also be proposed by students, provided they can find a suitable supervisor. Together with the core courses and the electives, tutorials help prepare students for the task of writing an MA thesis and/or help students explore a new field in depth. More so than in core courses and electives, the vast majority of the work is to be done by the students themselves. Students may in principle take tutorials in other humanities’ departments, depending on the availability of places and fulfilment of entrance requirements (a judgment that is to be made by the tutor), and provided the student can demonstrate the tutorial’s relevance to his or her programme.

Administration of tutorials: Each qualified tutor-giver will be enrolled in the blackboard site “Tutorial 1 Media Studies”. The tutorial has a generic code. Once a tutorial has been completed, the tutor fills in a so-called “bronbriefje”. This bronbriefje, which is to be handed in at the Onderwijsadministratie on the ground floor of BG1, specifies the generic code of the subject (“tutorial”), a mark between 0 and 10, the name of the tutor and the title of the tutorial, as well as a tutorial number: the codes for Media Studies students are:
First tutorial:
- Tutorial Ia Media Studies (160518506) - 6 EC
- Tutorial Ib Media Studies (160518516) - 6 EC (only as a further exploration of the same topic as Ia)
Second tutorial:
- Tutorial IIa Media Studies (160518526) - 6 EC
- Tutorial IIb Media Studies (160518536) - 6 EC (only as a further exploration of the same topic as IIa)
The third tutorial is a Thesis-related tutorial (see: Thesis-related Tutorial Media Studies (6 EC))
The student will tell the tutor whether this is her/his first, second, or third tutorial.

Note that for non-Media Studies Research Master students, the codes are different! Students from other Research Masters need to find out in their own department what the codes are. Note that the blackboard site provides opportunities for tutorial-givers to create a group, communicate with their tutor students, put on texts & links etc.

Note that the blackboard site provides opportunities for tutorial-givers to create a group, communicate with their tutor students, put on texts & links etc.
course.examination: Assignments, research tasks, and final paper

course.name: Writing Ethnography (MA Cultural and Social Anthropology)

programme.name: Master Culturele antropologie en sociologie der niet-westerse samenlevingen
Master's in Cultural and Social Anthropology

course.description:
Content
This course is to offer a platform for support, assistance, and a source of inspiration in the process of writing a master’s thesis in anthropology. At first instance, the emphasis will be on analysis and interpretation of the student’s own research material; of which the personal tutor, however, will have a final say. Subsequently attention will be paid to a range of genres and styles of writing based on the empirical material and theoretical framework presented, as well as on students’ personal skills and abilities. Creative writing as well as ethical considerations with respect to how to represent the Other will be stimulated by refreshing the students’ acquaintance with discussions held in anthropology after the Literary Turn since the 1980s.

Students have to write a section to be of their thesis for each weekly seminar and post their texts on Blackboard. They are encouraged to read each other’s texts and to offer comments and suggestions. The texts and the comments will be discussed during each seminar, so each will receive individual feedback. Next the attention that will be paid to linguistic issues, and matters of genre and style – as proposed in the program -, the tutor may also give out writing (or reading) assignments for a next week, depending on the particular problems that may come to the fore from the handed-in texts.
course.lecture_material:
Recommended:

ETNOFOOR 20(1) Writing Culture (2009), to be obtained at the reception desk of the Spinhuis and the tutor.

Clifford, James & George E. Marcus (eds.), 1986 , Writing Culture. The Poetics and Politics of Ethnography. Berkeley: University of California Press; Jacobson, David, 1991 , Reading Ethnography. New York: State University of NY.
course.goals: The course's objectives are is to provide students with better understanding of how to organize and structure their own research material into a written text. By tutoring students extensively during their process of writing up this course is to facilitate their efforts in finishing their thesis before the end of the semester. Besides the writing process students will also be prepared for presenting and defending their own work in a public setting.
course.specialities: The master thesis can be either in Dutch or in English. Naturally all texts handed in during this course should be written in the language of preferance.
course.examination: This course is to offer a platform for support, assistance, and a source of inspiration in the process of writing, to facilitate and improve the final aim: a well-written master’s thesis within time due.

course.name: Moleculaire Celbiologie BMW
course.year: Jaar 2 bachelor Bio-medische wetenschappen, bachelor Bèta-gamma_major Bio-medische wetenschappen, bachelor Bèta-gamma_major Neurobiologie en jaar 3 bachelor Psychobiologie_track Moleculaire Celbiologie
course.institute: College of Science domein Levens- en Aardwetenschappen
course.description:
De stof is verdeeld over drie vakgebieden, achtereenvolgens:
Biochemie:   

  • Eiwitstructuur en katalytische mechanismen.
  • Enzymkinetiek: Michaelis Menten kinetiek, affiniteitsconstante, competitieve/niet-competitieve remming, eiwitfosforylering.
  • Thermodynamische verklaringen voor enzym gekatalyseerde reacties.
  • Mechanismen van energieconservering.
  • Glycolyse, de citroenzuurcyclus en de ademhalingsketen.
  • Electronenoverdracht en redoxreacties.

Moleculaire biologie:

  • Structuur van DNA en RNA.
  • DNA-replicatie.
  • Regulatie van transcriptie in prokaryoten en eukaryoten.
  • RNA-processing.
  • Eiwitsynthese.
  • Moleculaire biologische technieken.

Celbiologie:

  • Structuur van de celmembraan en dynamische processen hierin.
  • Signaaloverdracht tussen cellen en binnen de cel.
  • Lipiden-afgeleide signaal moleculen.
course.timetable: Het rooster van deze cursus wordt gepubliceerd op https://datanose.nl/.
course.lecture_material:
• Hoofdstukken uit Molecular Biology of the Cell, 5 e druk, Alberts et al. Garland Publ. Inc. New York. 
  • Klapper voor onderdelen van celbiologie.
  • Additioneel ondersteunend materiaal op blackboard.
course.goals:
Het beheersen van basisbegrippen in de biochemie, moleculaire biologie en celbiologie het kunnen uitleggen van een aantal voorbeelden van:     

  • regulatie van genexpressie;
  • moleculair biologische technieken;
  • werking en regulatie van enzymen;
  • werking en regulatie van centrale biochemische routes;
  • de relaties tussen structuur en functie in cellulaire systemen.

Tevens kan de student de verworven inzichten toepassen op voorgelegde problemen.
course.examination:
Het tentamen bestaat uit twee deeltoetsen.
Het onderdeel biochemie/moleculaire biologie weegt even zwaar als het onderdeel celbiologie.
Voor celbiologie worden daarnaast twee ‘flitstoetsen’ gegeven die ieder voor 10% meetellen voor het onderdeel celbiologie

course.name: Operationele Research 1
course.description:
De volgende onderwerpen komen aan bod:

  • Lineaire Programmering (LP)
  • De Simplexmethode voor de oplossing van LP problemen    
  • Gevoeligheidsanalyse van LP problemen met de Simplexmethode    
  • Dualiteitsstellingen
  • Transportproblemen (TP) en hun oplossing m.b.v. dualiteit
  • Dynamische Programmering (DP)    
  • Enkele modelleertechnieken met binaire variabelen    
  • Gemengd Geheeltallige Programmering (MIP - Mixed Integer Programming)    
  • De Branch & Boundmethode voor (M)IP problemen    
  • Netwerkoptimalisatie problemen waaronder het kortste padprobleem  
  • Voorbeeldmodellen waaronder logistieke problemen, toewijzingsproblemen.

Naast het hoorcollege zijn er wekelijks een werkcollege en een PC-practicum. Op het werkcollege worden de OR-technieken geoefend via schriftelijke opdrachten, waarvan sommige klassikaal worden uitgewerkt. Tijdens het practicum implementeer je modellen op de PC; modellen die je zelf hebt opgesteld ter oplossing van een aantal mini-cases. Hierover wordt een practicumverslag ingeleverd.
course.lecture_material:
• P.A. Jensen & Jonathan F. Bard. Operations Research: Models and Methods. Wiley, ISBN 0-471-38004-0, ca. €57,25, verkrijgbaar bij boekhandel studystore;
  • hand-outs beschikbaar via Blackboard op https://blackboard.ic.uva.nl.
course.goals:
We streven de volgende doelen na:

  1. kennis van standaardtechnieken van de deterministische OR;    
  2. het kunnen herkennen van situaties die zich lenen voor lineaire programmering of (eenvoudige) dynamische programmering;    
  3. het kunnen formuleren van deze modellen; de implementatie op de computer en de terugvertaling van de uitkomsten naar de praktijk.
course.examination: Halverwege is er een individuele schriftelijke tussentoets over de leerstof van de eerste drie weken en aan het eind is er een tweede individuele schriftelijke toets over de resterende leerstof. Het eindcijfer bestaat uit: cijfer deeltoets (open vragen, drie uur, 30%), cijfer voor eindtoets (open vragen, drie uur, 50%) en cijfer voor PC-practicum (20%). Voor elk van de twee individuele onderdelen dient het cijfer minstens een 5.0 te zijn en het practicumverslag dient  voldoende te zijn. Het PC-practicum en het verslag daarvan kan in groepjes van twee worden gemaakt. Indien het cijfer onvoldoende is wordt een aanvullende opdracht gegeven. Resultaten voor de deeltoetsen blijven niet staan voor de herkansing (80%).

course.name: Duaal onderzoek III: Verdieping en reflectie
course.description: De student volgt samen met de studenten van de onderzoeksminor 15 EC het vak ‘Rechtswetenschappelijk onderzoek: verdieping en reflectie (3 EC)’. Daarnaast gebruikt de student de tijd in het derde blok om de bevindingen in het onderzoeksrapport in verband te brengen met het eerder verrichte literatuuronderzoek en met de wetenschapsfilosofische inzichten opgedaan in het eerste blok.
course.goals:
Dit vak draagt bij aan de wetenschappelijke vorming van de jurist. Na afloop van de cursus is de student in staat om:

  • verdieping aan te brengen op de onderzoeksresultaten van een zelf ontworpen en zelfstandig uitgevoerd onderzoek;
  • kritisch te reflecteren op de aard van wetenschappelijk onderzoek;
  • de beperkingen van wetenschappelijk onderzoek in te schatten;
  • ethische dilemma’s van onderzoekers te herkennen en in te schatten.
course.specialities: Dit vak maakt deel uit van de Minor Rechtswetenschappelijk onderzoek (30 EC variant) en kan niet zelfstandig gekozen worden.
course.examination: Schriftelijke opdrachten

course.name: Social Skills Lab: Leiding geven; effectieve gespreksvoering
course.description:
Hoewel ‘Leiding geven; effectieve gespreksvoering’ een goede voorbereiding is op een functie als leidinggevende, is de training ook voor studenten zonder leidinggevende ambities leerzaam. De cursus Leiding geven besteedt aandacht aan processen binnen en karakteristieken van taakgerichte groepen én aan leidinggevende vaardigheden. Deze zijn te onderscheiden in leiding geven aan groepen, in het bijzonder voorzittersvaardigheden, en dyadische gespreksvaardigheden. De vaardigheden van de leidinggevende bepalen vaak de effectiviteit van taakgerichte groepen. Daarbij is de crux het vinden van een balans tussen sociaal-emotionele en taakgerichte aspecten. Aan de orde komen individuele preferenties en groepsrollen, groepsstructuren, besluitvormingsprocedures, probleem oplossen, conflicthantering, debatteren, lobbyen en onderhandelen en als laatste, bemiddelen ofwel ‘mediation’. Iedere student zit een eigen voorbereide vergadering voor en analyseert deze naar aanleiding van de theorie. Bij dyadische gespreksvaardigheden kan men denken aan het voeren van slechtnieuws-, discipline-, functionerings- en beoordelingsgesprekken.

Houdt rekening met eventuele uitloop in tijden van de training. Totale omvang van de cursus is zeven weken, waarvan de eerste zes weken in trainingsvorm worden gegeven en de laatste week bedoeld is voor het schrijven van een eindverslag.
course.timetable:
Blok 1

  • Woe. & Do. 13-02-2013 t/m 21-03-2013 10.00-17.00 uur

Blok 2

  • Elke Ma. & Wo. startend i.v.m. Pinksteren op woensdag 22-05-2013 t/m 26-06-2013 10.00-17.00 uur*.
    * Inhaaldag voor Pinksteren op vrijdag 24-05-2013 van 10.00 tot 17.00 uur.
course.lecture_material: Benodigd materiaal wordt via Blackboard beschikbaar gesteld. (± 110 blz).
course.specialities: Aanwezigheid verplicht.
course.examination: Aanwezigheidsverplichting, beoordeling individuele opdracht (verslag en analyse van vergadering en andere programmaonderdelen).

course.name: Culturele en cognitieve musicologie I (incl. wetenschappelijk schrijven)

staff.name: prof. dr. W. van de Leur

course.description:
In deze module wordt een overzicht gegeven van culturele en cognitieve muziekwetenschap met aandacht voor jazz (blok 1), wereldmuziek (blok 2) en popmuziek (blok 3). Binnen dit cluster wordt parallel aan de colleges over deze drie onderwerpen tevens muziektheorie (blok 1 en 2) en academisch schrijven onderwezen.

Tijdens het onderdeel ‘Jazz’ maakt de student kennis met de rijke en veelkleurige traditie van jazz. Aan de orde komen de historiografie en theorievorming rondom verschillende jazzpraktijken en de discussies en problematiek die hiermee gepaard gaan. De voornaamste leerdoelen van deze cursus betreffen: Het verwerven van algemene analysevaardigheden en -technieken met betrekking tot muzikale improvisatie en notatie in muziek; Het verkrijgen van inzicht in de algemene theoretische vraagstukken rondom improvisatie en notatie; Kennisverbreding omtrent improvisatie en notatie in de jazzcultuur; Toepassing van theoretische vraagstukken op verschillende vormen van improvisatie in de jazzcultuur; Verdere bekwaming in de beginselen van het typeren, analyseren, en beschrijven van muzikale uitvoeringen uit de twintigste en eenentwintigste eeuw. Toetsing vindt plaats in de vorm van analyseopdrachten en essayvragen. Wereldmuziek wordt onderwezen in de vorm van een overzicht waarbij de diversiteit van muziek wereldwijd, evenals de interacties tussen verschillende muzikale tradities, voorop staat. Popmuziek wordt besproken vanuit een historisch perspectief. Hierbij komt de evolutie van en de relaties tussen de belangrijkste stromingen binnen de popmuziek aan bod, steeds geïllustreerd met een aantal case-studies.

Muziektheorie bestaat uit twee onderdelen, namelijk solfège (blok 1 en 2) en harmonieleer (blok 1 en 2). Bij solfège doet de student kennis op in de basisvaardigheden in solfège en gehoortraining. Dit bestaat uit een schriftelijk gedeelte, waarbij aandacht is voor ritmisch en melodisch dictee, het bepalen van tonale, en het herkennen en benoemen van samenklanken, en uit een mondeling gedeelte, met aandacht voor het ontwikkelen van vaardigheid in het ('a prima vista') van blad zingen. Tijdens harmonieleer leert de student harmonische progressies noteren en benoemen en harmonische analyses maken en bespreken. Studenten dienen solfège en harmonieleer in het eerste semester, als onderdeel van het cluster ‘Historische musicologie’, te hebben gevolgd om deel te nemen aan deze cursus.

In het onderdeel academisch schrijven staan argumenteren en schrijven centraal. De student maakt kennis met de eisen die aan de inhoud, de opbouw en de formulering van een overtuigend (wetenschappelijk) betoog worden gesteld. Daarbij wordt ingegaan op verschillende soorten standpunten, de argumentatiestructuur en de belangrijkste argumentatiefouten.
course.timetable:
Ca. 2x2 uur per week.

Raadpleeg vóór aanvang van de colleges het rooster voor locatie en tijd: https://rooster.uva.nl/.
course.lecture_material: Wordt bekend gemaakt via blackboard.
course.goals: De student heeft een overzicht en inzicht in de belangrijkste ontwikkelingen en thema’s op het gebied van jazz, wereldmuziek en popmuziek. Bij muziektheorie staat het verwerven van muzikale kennis en vaardigheden centraal. Dit behelst o.a. training van de algemene luistervaardigheid en muzieknotatie, het ontwikkelen van vaardigheid in het ('a prima vista') van blad zingen, en het aanleren van vaardigheid in het maken van eenvoudige harmonische zettingen. Tijdens academische schrijven leren studenten op een academisch niveau te formuleren en beargumenteren.
course.examination:
• De onderdelen jazz, wereldmuziek en popmuziek worden afzonderlijk afgerond met een schriftelijk tentamen en repertoiretoets aan het einde van respectievelijk blok 1, 2 en 3.
  • Muziektheorie wordt afgesloten aan de hand van een schriftelijk en mondeling tentamen aan het einde van blok 2.
  • Hertentamens vinden plaats aan het eind van blok 3.
  • Academische vaardigheden wordt afgesloten met een kort werkstuk.
  • Voor de onderdelen van muziektheorie geldt verder:
    • het maken van de opdrachten (verstrekt op de werkcolleges) is verplicht;
    • praktische oefening is voor deze module essentieel. De student dient er rekening mee te houden dat hiervoor veel tijd vrij gemaakt zal moeten worden;
    • na het eerste college kan niet meer worden ingestroomd.

De zes onderdelen (muziekgeschiedenis I, II, en III, harmonieleer, solfège en onderzoeksvaardigheden) wegen allemaal even zwaar mee in de bepaling van het eindcijfer.

course.name: Het Italiaans in de samenleving
course.description:
N.B. Deze module bestaat uit drie onderdelen:

Taal en maatschappij

Bij Taal en Maatschappij gaat het over de relatie tussen de Italiaanse taal en de maatschappij die deze taal heeft voortgebracht en gebruikt. Aan bod komen thema’s als taalvariatie (de relatie tussen standaardtaal, dialecten, en lokale en sociale varianten van het Italiaans); de relatie met andere talen buiten Italië, bijvoorbeeld onder emigranten; taalpolitiek en tweetaligheid. Een gedeelte van de colleges zal gewijd zijn aan de argumentatieve structuur van enkele taalvariëteiten, zoals bijvoorbeeld reclametaal en de taal van de politiek.

Italiaanse cultuur en schrijfvaardigheid

Bij Italiaanse cultuur en schrijfvaardigheid ligt het accent op schrijfvaardigheid, die wordt getraind aan de hand van cultuurhistorische thema’s. Voor elk college bestuderen studenten teksten, essays, films en ander materiaal. Tijdens college of thuis schrijven studenten teksten en leveren deze in als onderdeel van het dossier (onder andere een betogend of verhalend opstel, een samenvatting, een herschreven tekst(gedeelte), antwoorden op vragen over een leestekst, een analyse van taalkundige aspecten).

Redigeren en argumenteren

Bij Redigeren en argumenteren worden verschillende lees-, spreek- en luisteractiviteiten verricht ter voorbereiding op het schrijven van teksten en het houden van discussies en voordrachten. Het analyseren en herschrijven van teksten en het feedback geven op mondelinge opdrachten staan centraal. Er wordt vooral aandacht besteed aan lexicale, grammaticale en stilistische kenmerken van de verschillende (mondelinge en schriftelijke) genres.
course.lecture_material:
Taal en maatschappij

  • reader met artikelen (verkrijgbaar bij docent)

Redigeren en argumenteren & Italiaanse cultuur en schrijfvaardigheid

  • D. Corno, Scrivere e comunicare. Teoria e pratica della scrittura in lingua italiana, Mondadori, Milano, 2002
  • G. Patota, Grammatica di riferimento dell’italiano contemporaneo
  • De Agostini Scuola – Garzanti Linguistica, Novara, 1e uitgave 2006
  • De grote Zingarelli of een ander eentalig woordenboek.
course.goals: Kennis van de complexiteit van het hedendaagse Italiaans en van zijn dialectale context; kennis van de contemporaine Italiaanse cultuurgeschiedenis aan de hand van teksten en andere cultuuruitingen; schrijf- en argumentatievaardigheid aan de hand van teksten van uiteenlopende genres.
course.examination:
Taal en maatschappij

  • tussentoets (week 14, één uur, 20%)
  • eindtoets (week 19, twee uur, 60%)
  • dossier met opdrachten (20%)

herkansing

  • Herkansing (week 20; twee uur, 80%); het cijfer voor het dossier blijft staan (20%).

Redigeren en argumenteren

  • Dossier bestaande uit schriftelijke en mondelinge opdrachten, waarvan een deel tijdens de lessen wordt uitgevoerd (100%).

herkansing

  • Schriftelijk en mondeling toets (week 20, drie uur).

Italiaanse cultuur en schrijfvaardigheid

  • Dossier (100%) bestaande uit schriftelijke opdrachten die thuis of tijdens het college zijn gemaakt. De student dient alle opdrachten van het dossier op tijd in te leveren. Deelname aan colleges waarin opdrachten worden uitgevoerd is een voorwaarde om de module af te ronden. Studenten die een onvolledig dossier inleveren krijgen geen toegang tot de herkansing. De laatste schriftelijke opdracht van het dossier vindt plaats in blok 3 (drie uur).

herkansing

  • Schriftelijke toets (week 20, drie uur, 100%) bestaande uit een verhalende of argumentatieve tekst.

course.name: System Innovation and Transition Management
course.institute: Master School of Life and Earth sciences
course.description:
Over the past few decades, there has been a growing concern about the social and environmental risks which have come along with the progress achieved through a variety of mutually intertwined modernization processes. In recent years these concerns are transformed into a widely-shared sense of urgency, partly due to events such as the various pandemics threatening livestock, increasing awareness of the risks and realities of climate change, and the energy and food crises. This sense of urgency includes an awareness that our entire social system is in need of fundamental transformation. But like the earlier transition between the 1750's and 1890's from a pre-modern to a modern industrial society, this second transition is also a contested one. Sustainable development is only one of many options. In this course we address the issue on how to understand the dynamics and governance of the second transition dynamics in order to ensure sustainable development and long-term transformative change.

Point of departure forms the comprehensive research programme that the Knowledge network for System Innovations (KSI) has executed over the last six years (UvA in corporation with the Erasmus University Rotterdam and the Technical University Eindhoven). In this research programme efforts have been made to put transition thinking into practice in various domains, including those concerned with Climate Change, Energy and Agriculture. In our course, we will draw from this concrete practices to learn more about transformative change in real life.

Themes:

1. Dynamics of Transitions: A Socio-Technical Perspective

2. A Systemic & Reflexive Approach to Transitions

3. Understanding Transitions from a Governance Perspective
course.lecture_material:
Point of departure of the SITM course is the comprehensive book:

Grin, J., Rotmans, J. & J. Schot (2010) Transitions to Sustainable Development. New Directions in the Study of Long-Term Transformative Change, New York / London: Routledge.

Also, additional literature will be used, which can be found in either one of the university libraries or downloaded via the web.
course.goals:
• Acquiring insights in the main theoretical concepts supporting Multi-Level Perspectives on transition thinking and innovation theories, particularly Science & Technology Studies.
  • Gaining deeper insight in one particular transformative domain.
  • Acquiring experience with the technique of Integrated Assessment.
  • Augmenting academic writing skills and the use of social media (blogging).
  • Acquiring competencies as innovators.
